titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V: Tuesday. At the Office, Captain Low came, and I gave him the Letters to C. S. Todd and Dr Forsyth. He wanted a Passport for his vessel which would protect him from capture by the Spaniards in going up the river Orinoco; but I could not give him one, especially as he takes with him a Cargo of Flour for the Patriots. I made a draft of a Letter to C. N. Buck, Consul General from Hamburg, in answer to one received lately from him. Went to Mr Crawford’s Office to consult with him upon various points— Found that he had just left the City for Georgia. Answered a Letter lately received from William King, Governor of the State of Maine, which enclosed a Resolution of the Legislature concerning the Settlement of the boundary of the State, by the Commission under the fifth Article of the Treaty of Ghent. Wrote also to the Commissioner C. P. Van Ness, and sent him by direction from the President copies of Governor King’s Letter and of the Resolution. Wrote finally to the President— It was near six O’Clock, when I got home. Day and Evening showery with thunder.

2. IV:15. I received yesterday a Letter from Josiah Quincy at Boston, concerning my books now deposited at the Athenaeum; which he proposes to remove to rooms of his own, and to keep for me, four years. Began this morning an answer accepting the proposal. At the Office, I wrote a short Letter to the Collector of the Port of Norfolk making enquiries concerning the case of the Pirating privateer Wilson. The rest of the Office hours I was engaged examining the old English Statutes upon weights and Measures— A Chaos from which it seems as if I never should emerge— The absorption of time by the current Office business, the bath, the newspapers and the Journal, leaves me so little for weights and measures that I dread the approach of the next Session of Congress, lest it should find me with my report still unprepared— I must borrow from the Journal and the newspapers. Mrs Adams and the Children spent the Evening abroad.

3. IV:30. Bath in the river alone. At the Office I wrote a short Letter to T. B. Waite, and another to A. Shepherd. I am now occupied about an hour every day in franking packets of the Laws of the last Session of Congress addressed to the Governors of the States and Territories. I took up again the old English Acts of Parliament upon weights and measures, and read Raynardson’s paper upon them in Postlethwait’s Dictionary. Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening— It was again sultry and calm; so that after dusk I could only betake myself to bed.

4 V: At the Office, received a Despatch and a private Letter from J. Forsyth, at Madrid, and Letters from the Marshal of the District of Georgia, and Captain Jackson of the Revenue Cutter Dallas, concerning which I found it necessary to consult Mr Calhoun, the Secretary at War— I therefore sent to request him to call at my Office which he did. I had received a note from the French Chargé d’Affaires Roth mentioning that the French Minister of Marine was sending a Lighter to take away a number of Cannon belonging to the French Government; which have been several years lying at Baltimore, and asking an exemption in favour of this vessel, from the operation of a Law of the last Session of Congress limiting the Ports into which foreign armed vessels are to be admitted, in which Baltimore is not included. But the Law has left no discretionary power with the Executive— The President had desired me to speak to the other heads of Departments, concerning the regulations to be prescribed for the execution of this Law—but when I called at the Treasury for this purpose, Mr Crawford was gone, and I now found that Mr Calhoun was yet waiting to know what regulations had been adopted at the Treasury. I wrote to the President upon these and other subjects. In the evening I called at Mr Ramsay’s to see Mr John Graham; but he was so ill that I could not see him— Mrs Graham and the Relations have given up all hopes of his recovery; and last Night he was so low that they feared his immediate dissolution. There has been this day a consultation of physicians upon his case, and some change of treatment for his disease, but from the rapidity of his decline since his arrival here, I think he will not survive many days. I called afterwards at W. S. Smith’s— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen were spending the Evening there— Also Mr and Mrs R. Cutts.

5. V: A man by the name of Thompson, belonging to Baltimore, came to the Office, arrived recently from Spain. He was one of those who went from Baltimore with the younger Mina, to Mexico— Was there at the time of his disaster taken prisoner, and sent to Spain, and afterwards to the Coast of Africa, where he has been kept in prison about three years; and liberated by the general release of State prisoners, Citizens of the United States, obtained of the Spanish Government since the Revolution of the present year— He appeared to think that he had very important information to communicate, which amounted to this—That Mr Herrera, one of the most distinguished members of the Cortes of 1812. and the person who in 1814. presented to Ferdinand 7. The Constitution for his acceptance, was immediately afterwards cast into prison— That Thompson was confined in the same prison, and was intimate acquainted with him— That he foresaw and foretold the change which has taken place in Spain; and told Thompson that the Cortes would not ratify the Florida Treaty—and that this Mr Herrera is now Minister of Grace and Justice, and Prime Minister of Spain— Mr Evans the Baptist Clergyman, who came with Mrs Cornell, was also at the Office to enquire, if an answer had been received from the President, upon her application. It had not yet come; the papers having been kept three or four days by Mr Wirt, and not despatched to the President till this week. Evans asked my opinion of the case which I candidly gave him; and which was not favourable to the convict. I think nevertheless that the President will reprieve and pardon him— Evans said that he had not been acquainted with Mrs Cornell, or the case of her Son, till he providentially met her in a Steam-boat, coming to this place— He said he should leave the City on his return home, next Monday. Most of the Office hours this day were engaged in looking over the English Statutes on weights and measures; and Smith’s Wealth of Nations, to trace the natural connection between money weights and commeasures. This Evening was so cool that I was enabled to read the Newspapers by Candlelight.

6. V:30.Cardelli was here this Morning to take leave— He is going with his associates to Baltimore to-morrow. They have sold all the Casts of the Busts that he has made here; and are now going to try their Fortune elsewhere. We all attended Church at Mr M’Cormick’s— He read prayers for the tenth Sunday after Trinity, and his Sermon was from Genesis XXII.1.2. And it came to pass after these things that God did tempt Abraham, and said unto him, “Abraham: and he said, Behold, here I am: And he said, Take now thy son, thine only son Isaac, whom thou lovest and get thee into the land of Moriah; and offer him there for a burnt offering upon one of the mountains which I will tell thee of.” It was a communion day Sermon which commenced by remarks, on the astonishing character of the Event therein commemorated, seemingly more suited to a cruel deity like Moloch, than to the gracious and merciful Jehovah— The subject then was considered according to the incidents attending it as related in the context; followed by practical reflections applicable to the auditory— The severity of the divine injunction, the terrible struggle in the heart of Abraham between his duty of obedience to God, and his faith on one hand, and his affection for his child, his beloved son, the child of a miracle, the child of promise that in his seed all the nations of the Earth should be blessed, on the other, was well described—the submission of Isaac then upwards of thirty years of age; the pathetic occurrences of the Journey and of the Story till Abraham had the knife raised to bury it in the bowels of his child were all noticed— The interposition of the Angel at the moment of the Catastrophe, and the rewards of Abraham’s obedience, led to the practical reflections of Instruction to Christians, of reproof to Sinners, and of Consolation to the afflicted and bereaved which resulted from the subject— The Instruction was Faith and Obedience to the divine commands— Obedience, universal, willing and prompt. The reproof to sinners was for their disobedience; so inexcusable by its contrast to the submission of Abraham—the command to him requiring a conquest over the strongest affections and most virtuous feelings of nature; and the commands to them—being only the sacrifice of Passions which lead to wretchedness and destruction— The consolation to the bereaved, within the assurance given by God in the Event of this History, that he will reward the faithful, and has a power always ready to wipe the tears from the eyes of human sufferance. He concluded by considering this threatened but averted sacrifice, as the typical and prophetical
representation of the great sacrifice of Jesus Christ; a sacrifice by God, of his only begotten, and beloved Son, upon the same spot. A sacrifice which no hand of an angel arrested; but which was actually consummated— The transition now was easy to an exhortation of attendance to the ordinance of the communion; which was earnest and vehement; but in substance the same which he gave on Whitsunday. Mr M’Cormick dwells with so much urgency upon this duty, and holds out the neglect of it as so criminal, that he almost startles me while I hear him. I do not however subscribe to his doctrine of the indispensable necessity of partaking of the dispensation of this ordinance— I recollected having once heard at New-York, a Sermon from this text, by the late Dr Smith, President of Princeton College, and found by truing to my Journal it was on the 17th. of November 1805. and that my only remark upon it was, that it was a difficult subject— I have since then written some remarks upon it to my Son George— The mystical part of it, the typical image of the sacrifice of Jesus Christ on the same mount is altogether beyond my comprehension— God was not the father of Jesus Christ, as Abraham was the father of Isaac— The term Son, as applied to Christ, in his relation to God the Father conveys a false idea to the mind— It is a figurative father; and if the sacrifice of his life in his human nature was painful; why did he ordain it as necessary? That omnipotence should suffer pain, is absurd; that it should deliberately inflict pain upon itself is ridiculous—that it should sacrifice itself to atone for the guilt of others incurred by its own predetermined acts and will, is at once absurd, ridiculous and unjust. Thus much for human reason— Faith is founded upon other promises— With Mrs Adams I spent this Evening at Mr Calhoun’s— Mr John Graham died this day at Mr Ramsey’s, at 1/2 past one O’Clock; and we received an invitation to attend his funeral to-morrow Morning at 8.

7. V:30. With Mrs Adams I attended this Morning at 8 O’Clock the funeral of Mr John Graham. There was no religious service performed at the house— The procession went from Mr Ramsay’s house about ten— We followed it as far as the Eastern branch bridge and thence returned— He was to be buried at Marlborough in Prince George’s County, Maryland. At the Office the Baptist Clergyman Evans called again, not having left the City as he had— He came to enquire, if there was an answer from the President for Mrs Cornell, but there was none— I wrote a draft of a Letter to A. Gallatin, and one to the Marshal of Indiana Vawter, containing complaints against him for misconduct— The day and evening were cool and showery.

8. V:45. Engaged with Weights and Measures at home; and when once I take them up, other business must be sacrificed. I have plunged into a historical review of English Legislation upon this subject: it is called for by the Resolutions of the two Houses, but it widens and spreads as I pursue my researches, and I dread the want of time to finish it before the Meeting of Congress— The current business of the Office too engrosses all my time there— A Mr Selden of Virginia appointed a judge for the territory of Arkansaw came to the Office. He was appointed in June and then wrote to me to ask for Instructions. I had none to give, but wrote him it was desirable that he should repair as speedily as possible to his Post— He came now apparently to tell me that he could not go till the first of October, from the difficulty of descending the Mississippi, and the unhealthiness of the Country at this time— There have been two or three judges appointed for that Territory, who held the Office and received the Salary, one of them for a whole year, without even going there, and then resigned. Selden seems disposed to follow the example. I received a second and angry Letter from Roth, about the new Tonnage duty upon French Vessels. I wrote to the President, and to Governor Clark of Georgia. The W. S. Smith’s spent the Evening here.

9. V: Bath in the river alone: occupied at home till past noon with the draft of a Report upon Weights and Measures. At the Office, Dr Tucker the Treasurer came with a Mr Dashiels, from New-Orleans who has an application pending for a Patent— But as he is deaf, occasioned by the Cannonading at the Battle
of New-Orleans, he said he would come at One O’Clock to-morrow, with Dr Thornton, and explain his objects— I had the two Patent Scales which I some time since procured from Boston taken from their boxes and set up in the Library chamber of the Department— Wrote to the U.S. District Attorney in Georgia, Habersham— The Summer heat is returning— Mrs Adams and the children rode out this Evening. I read the Newspapers.

10. III: Saw Sirius rise and for a full half hour after he had risen— He rose at a quarter past four. I had last year fixed so precisely the spot of his rising that I now perceived him the moment he was above the horizon. By the rising of this Star, the rotatory motion of the earth from West to East, is more perceptible to the eye, than by the rising or setting of the Son or Moon— At the Office, Mr Shields came, but without Dr Thornton, who is indisposed. Shields gave me a Letter stating his claim which is of a Patent right, acquired by him as a creditor of the inventor, who has failed. Shields has nothing but this patent right—for a debt of three thousand dollars, and now the inventor is applying for a new Patent, which will entirely supersede the old one, upon the pretext of an improvement to his invention. Shields says it is no improvement at all. The Law provides that questions of this kind shall be settled by Arbitration; and Shields’s application is that no new Patent may issue to his debtor, till arbitrators shall have decided whether he is entitled to it. I tried this day the two sets of Balances received from Pollock at Boston, and found them in good order. The Largest pair, are sensible to one tenth of a grain Troy weight— The Alexandria Standard avoirdupois Pound weighs only 6949.6 Grains which is 50.4 Grains too light— My French Kilogramme weighs barely and hardly 15438. The same that I had found it by Dearborn’s Scales at the Branch Bank. The Amsterdam Pound also, as there weighs 7631 Grains— I wrote to the President. Fahrenheit at 90, and the heat almost insupportable.

11. IV: The heat continues intense, by which I have again lost the power of reading after the dusk of the Evening. The morning occupation upon weights and measures suffers by it— I find intenseness of heat incompatible with intenseness of application— Mrs Adams, with Charles and Mary Hellen spent the day at Mr Frye’s. At the Office came a Mr Carberry, a member of the Common Council of the City of Washington— They are about beginning to build a City Hall; and he came to ask a Register of the Officers of the General Government, as last published; to put with some other documents into the corner Stone— I wrote several Letters concerning the collection of the State Laws, for the Department— By a Resolution of Congress of 23. September 1789. it is made the duty of the Secretary of State to procure from time to time, such of the Statutes of the several States as may not be in his Office— This Resolution has never been carried systematically into effect— The removals, changes, and fires, together with the British invasion in 1814, and the want of system in the administration of the Department, had reduced its library almost to nothing. There were no regulations for keeping it. Any body took out Books from it, and no one was responsible for the return of them. They were accordingly all in broken sets— Mr Rush while acting in the Department had written a circular requesting the District Attornies to procure and forward the Statutes of the several States where they resided, which some of them had answered and some had not. Until the new Offices were built there was neither Library room nor Shelves nor Librarian— With the view of introducing a better order of things I had an apartment laid out in the new building to which the Office was last summer transferred, equal in extent to two of the other Rooms, and appropriated it to the Library. Shelves were procured for putting up the Books— I charged the youngest Clerk in the Department Thruston with the custody of the Library, and directed him to let no book go out without a minute of it being made, and notice given to the person taking it, that he must be responsible for its return— And now I undertook to obtain a collection of the State Statutes— I wrote last November a circular to all the District Attornies, requesting each of them to send me, a Statement of every edition of
the Statutes of the State, whether in the Colonial Condition, or since Independence, and to procure and send me a copy of every one of them that could be obtained at a moderate price— The answers have been coming in from time to time ever since; and there are three or four from whom no answer is yet received. The pressure of other business, has made it impossible for me to attend to every Letter as it came in— I have now a Collection almost complete of the Statutes of the States, but there are still wanting those of Virginia, North-Carolina, Tennessee; and the territory of Missouri; and those of several other States are yet incomplete— To keep the collection complete when made, we must receive from twenty-four States, and two Territories, from year to year, and from some of the States twice a year, the Laws passed at every Session of the Legislature— To effect this I wrote last Winter a circular to the Governors of the States, requesting them to furnish the Department with a copy of their Laws from Session to Session, and suggesting to them the example of Massachusetts, which by a Resolution of the Legislature, sends four copies of its Laws, one for the President, one for each house of Congress, and one for the Library of Congress. Some of the Governors have complied—others have taken no notice of my Letter; and as the Governors of the States themselves are changing from year to year, and the successor will probably have no knowledge of my Letter to his predecessor, this expedient will not answer the purpose— I this day bethought myself of writing a circular to the Official Printer of the State Laws in every State; requesting him to furnish one copy of the Statutes from Session to Session—and I made a draft of such a circular— The District Attorneys of Virginia had suspended the execution of my orders to procure the respective Statutes, and in January had written Letters asking explanations of my first Letter. When theirs were received I was driven by other more urgent business, from immediately replying, and laid by their Letters for a moment of leisure which I have not found till this day— I now replied to them. It also occurred to me as necessary to draw up a Letter of Instruction to Thruston as keeper of the Library— This will require more leisure. It was near seven O’Clock when I dined— Mrs Adams and the children came home while I was at dinner. Mrs Tayloe and her daughter and Mr Roth came to pay visits but were not received.

12. IV: The heat of the Night was so excessive that I scarcely slept at-all; rose at four and witnessed the rising of Sirius; noting also a number of the minor Stars of Orion that I had never before remarked— The day was as inflammatory as the Night, and even my dog, wanders about the chamber, lolling out the tongue and panting for breath, the Thermometer at 92— At the office, I pursued the subject of examining the State Statutes Collection, which I found yet very imperfect and wanting arrangement— There was a hunt of an hour or two for books and Letters, which I wanted and which were not to be found— I wrote several short Letters. Mr Gouverneur the Presidents Son-in-Law called at the Office. He is just from the President’s in Albemarle, with his wife, and after spending a week here, they are going to New-York. The boys, Thomas Hellen and Robert Buchanan dined with us, and Mr Thomas Cook, came in while we were at dinner. The Evening was almost suffocating.

13. IV: Another day of all-enervating heat. We all attended Church at Mr M’Cormick’s. He read Prayers for the eleventh Sunday after Trinity, and preached from 1. Timothy IV:12. “Let no man despise thy Youth.” It was a discourse addressed especially to the young people of his auditory, and was I suppose written by himself. After expatiating upon the importance of laying in youth the foundation for respectability of character, he proceeded to give advice upon those means by which they might best recommend themselves to the good opinion of the wise, and virtuous— They were 1. Christian piety. 2 Caution in the formation of their Sentiments. 3. Reading. 4. Diligence. 5. Choice of their Company; and Recreations 6. Filial duty: after which he returned to the first as including all the rest; with an earnest exhortation to piety. It was altogether a good plain sermon for the edification of those to whom it was addressed, though neither in the choice or arrangement of topics, nor in language or composition elegant and harmonious like the Sermon upon the Sabbath, and some others. He did not touch upon the most important topics of the subject the controul and regulation of the Passions. Nor on Habits or
manners; nor on the vices which are most dangerous to youth— After returning home I found myself incapable of writing for the remainder of the day. I read the despatches and Letters which came by the Mail. The whole of the first Epistle to Timothy, and part of Hewlett’s Commentary upon it. Mr Calhoun, and Mr and Mrs Cutts called and spent an hour of the Evening with us— Calhoun is going upon an excursion of six weeks to the North and is to leave the City on Tuesday Morning— There was the first part of this day a breeze just perceptible from the East, in the afternoon it came round to the Southwest, which is the permanent quarter of hot wind.

14. V: This Diary had run back nearly three days, and this Morning was devoted to retrieve them— An Eastern breeze like that of yesterday freshened the atmosphere partially. About noon, I rode to the Potowmack river and bathed there was none of the breeze upon the river; the surface of which was glassy—the water nearly blood-warm, and the Sun scorching— At the Office I received a Letter from the President, and a large packet of despatches returned. but there were none of the papers, concerning the petition for the pardon of Cornell, nor a word in the Letter upon the case. Bestor came from Mrs Cornell to enquire if the President’s answer was received— I was obliged to put him off, and wrote to the President— He in his Letter appeared to think that the Executive could dispense with the execution of the Law for limiting the number of Ports at which foreign armed vessels are allowed to enter; so that the French Vessel coming for Cannon may go to Baltimore, and the British Frigate bringing out a Minister may enter at Annapolis. And he desired me to take the opinion of the other members of the administration now here, on the question— I called therefore at the War Office, and consulted Mr Calhoun— The attorney General having gone of yesterday to the Berkley Springs in Virginia. Calhoun thought the cases not of sufficient importance to warrant the assumption of a dispensing power, none being given by the Act— I had also some Conversation with Calhoun, upon several other subjects— The heat of this Evening was less oppressive than it has been the five preceding Nights.

15. IV: About three this Morning there came up one of those terrific thunder showers, which here almost universally succeed a turn of hot weather. There was little wind; still Eastern; which the thunder cloud met, rising from the West and proceeding slowly till it covered the horizon. There were in a space of fifteen minutes five dazzling flashes of Lightening, and thunderbolt’s in the immediate vicinity of the house. A house in the neighbourhood of ours was struck— The movement of the electrical collision was from North to South, and about 8 in the morning it returned from South to North, with moderated force of rain, thunder and lightening— The Showers returned at intervals through the day, and evening, without much abatement of the heat— Yet the evening was so far cooled that I read the newspapers with windows closed, and by Candle-light. From the experience of the two preceding summers I consider this as the breaking up of the excessive Night heats of Summer; and that henceforth, the Evenings will be no longer, or at least very seldom, total losses to occupation— I wrote a Letter to J. P. Van Ness, about his deed of the place which I purchased of Edwards— At the Office I made some further experiments upon Pollock’s Scales; but upon attempting to weigh the Cologne weight of 50 marks, it forced the Scales, and separated the soldered brass ring which linked the Scale to the brass chain by which it was suspended— It also brought the beam itself with violence down from the Agate upon which it was poised— I found therefore two faults in my own mode of making the experiments, and two faults in Pollock’s Scales— My errors were; in not perceiving before hand that the Scales were not strong enough to bear so heavy a weight— This was the greater, because Thruston who was with me did express a doubt before I made the trial—and in not securing the beam, within a channeled brass groove, provided for the purpose— The faults of the Scales are that the axis of the beam is not pinioned, and is thus constantly liable to the accident, which now happened; and the second that the Construction of the Scales is altogether too Slight, scarcely suitable to bear without straining, a weight of ten Pounds— I found I could not restore the ring to its rotundity, and the Scales now require to be repaired— Bestor called at the Office for Mrs Cornell, but I had yet no answer for her from the President— I made a draft of Instructions to Thruston, for the keeping of the Library
and answered a Letter of invitation from C. J. Ingersoll at Philadelphia. My draft of a Report upon weights and measures in the mean time slumbers. Mrs Adams, with Charles and Mary Hellen went this day and drank the Waters at Bladensburg.

16. VI: Another showery day, beginning however to be cooler; at the Office, I received a Letter and several enclosures from the Governor of Georgia, to which I drafted an answer, and wrote also to the President. Made some further examination of the collection of the Statutes of the States, yet very incomplete; and the obtaining and keeping of which complete will require system and perseverance— I found three or four volumes of the Laws of Massachusetts, still missing, and am to write to G. Blake for them— I received a Letter from J. B. Colvin, who has been these last eight or ten days absent from the Department, for which he offers a candid apology. He is when at the Office, the most effective clerk in it; but has occasional fits of intemperance which seize him like a distemper; last from a week to a fortnight; and during which he does not make his appearance, and is not to be found. He promises reformation for the future— Several of our domestics at the house were unwell.

17. V:Mr Mariano came to my house, and solicited again for employment. He brought me a Letter from C. S. Todd at St Thomas, giving him some encouragement to go and join him: but I could give him none— His pretensions are in such contrast with his circumstances, that it is impossible to do any thing for him— He brought me a list of his books at very extravagant prices; of which I agreed to take a number sufficient to pay him for them, and for the translations which he made for me, and for which he would not accept pay— At the Office there came a young man, named Barnhouse, belonging to the State of Ohio, but last from Winchester Virginia. He said he was nephew to Mr Worthington, formerly Governor of Ohio, and wanted employment as a Clerk in any of the Offices— I could give him none— He then said he had applied some time since for a Midshipman’s Warrant, and had a recommendation from Governor Tiffin— I gave him one for B. Homans, Chief Clerk in the Navy Department— I received a Letter from J. P. Van Ness, to which I replied. Wrote to the French Charge d’Affaires, Roth, and began a Letter to J. Forsyth— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here.

18. IV:30.Charles’ birth-day. 13. The weights and measures engaged me so that I found hardly time enough for the Journal of yesterday— Upon whatsoever I begin in the Morning, it engrosses my time so that I have none left for any-thing else— At the Office I found two Letters and packets from the President; with directions, which I cannot execute in the absence of the Secretaries of the Treasury, and of War, and of the Attorney General— I only finished the draft of a Letter to J. Forsyth, and passed the rest of the Office hours, in the Library. Day and Evening cool.

19. IV:15. Bath in the Potowmack alone. Returned home just as the Sun rose. Took up my draft of a Report upon Weights and Measures, in which new Views present themselves the farther I proceed, and the more I meditate— The Resolutions of the two Houses calling for a Report, embrace three objects. 1. A Statement of the regulations of the several States— 2 Of the proceedings of foreign Nations to establish uniformity, of weights and measures 3. An opinion what measures it would be proper to adopt by the Government of the Union. The plan I have formed is to invert the order of the first and second branches of the Resolutions— To state first the Proceedings of foreign Nations; secondly the regulations of the States; and lastly the opinion of what ought to be done— But this opinion must be deduced 1. from abstract reasoning upon the nature of the subject. 2. From what is practicable 3. From the Constitutional powers of Congress, And the whole is to be connected together so that the opinion shall result from the abstract reasoning, and the experience of what is practicable proved by the result of the proceedings of other Nations and our own. This plan I adopted when I first began to draft the Report and I see no reason to change it; but the subject and is great and complicated, and in treating it I find “hills over hills and Alps on Alps arise.” At the
Office, I had a large mail, and consequently, wrote only part of a Letter to the President— It was upon the affair of the Bulloch’s at Savannah; an affair upon which I scarcely dare trust myself to think. The delays and hesitation of the President and the connivence of Crawford in regard to these most infamous transactions have forced me to push the subject again and again— Two of the Bulloch’s, one of whom is the collector of the Port of Savannah, have against them the most violent presumptive evidence of having committed crimes punishable with death— The third has strong presumptive evidence against him of misprision of the same crimes— But one of the Bulloch’s has been a Senator of the United States; and another the Collector, married the daughter of the present Senator Elliot; they are all men of consequence in the State of Georgia, and open standing puffers of Crawford’s pretensions to the Presidency— It sickens me to the heart to be forced to action this case; but a duty paramount to every other consideration urges me; and I will not shrink from it. Read the Newspapers in the Evening.

20. V: The Night was cool, and my morning Heralds, Venus and Sirius had risen half an hour before me— I could still discern Venus after the Sun had risen— Mrs Adams was unwell. The rest of us attended Church and heard Mr M’Cormick read Prayers for the 12th. Sunday after Trinity and preach from Matthew XVI.13–19. the important passage, where Peter first proclaims Jesus to be the Messiah; and where Jesus pronounces Peter the Rock upon which he will build his Church, against which the Gates of Hell should not prevail; and promises him the keys of Heaven; and the power to bind and loose in Heaven, whatever he shall bind and loose upon Earth— This discourse glanced as might be expected, on one side at the Unitarians, and on the other at the Roman Catholics. Its divisions were, the occasion upon which it happened, the design of Jesus in its occurrence, and the use which has been made of it; particularly by the Romish Church, in the pretension that St. Peter was Bishop of Rome, and that the gifts bestowed upon him were also bestowed upon his Successors— After returning home I wrote to my Son George— Mrs Adams and the children spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s— I took a solitary walk.

21. IV:30. Bath alone. The Abbe Correa, Portuguese Minister called upon me this morning; just returned from, a visit in Virginia, to Messrs.Jefferson and Madison, and the President— I had much conversation with him, upon our differences with Portugal, which arise principally from the piratical depredations committed upon Portuguese commerce and subjects by vessels armed and fitted out in our Ports, cruizing under the flag of Artigas— He was moderate in his tone of complaint, and professed to be satisfied with the assurances I gave him of my own earnest desire and the disposition of the President to put down these practices. He will however write to me on the subject— At the Office, General Parker came, with a Letter from a Merchant at New-York, informing him that upwards of twenty whaling and Sealing vessels have been fitted out at New-York this Summer, to go to an island or Continent, discovered in the South Sea, almost directly South of Cape Horn, about two years ago, by an English Captain of a merchant vessel from Chili. This New-York Gentleman wishes that possession may be taken of that Island, in the name of the United States and engages to have a permanent settlement made there— And solicits that one of the Public Ships may be ordered to protect the Settlement, and take the formal possession. I promised General Parker to send the Letter to the President, and desired him to advise his friend to write again with more particulars; and also to see and converse with the Secretary of the Navy, Thompson, who is at New-York about sending the public Ship. I examined the map, and marked the spot where this new discovery is said to be— It is mentioned in a Letter from J. B. Prevost, and much more particularly in one from Jeremy Robinson. I wrote to the President— Mr Roth, the French Charge d’Affaires called this Evening while we were at dinner— He is going to-morrow Morning to Wilmington, where the vessel lies which he is about despatching to France, and which he told me would not sail before the 25th of this Month. The tonnage
duty of 18 dollars per ton on French Vessels laid by the act of Congress of 15 May last, has excited great resentment in France, and Roth can hardly keep his temper about it. He said a retaliatory duty of 100 franks a ton upon American Vessels arriving in France after the first of July had been laid— I had seen such a report from the Newspapers, but told Roth I had not believed it, supposing the king could not levy taxes without the consent of the Legislative Chambers; but he said he could. Roth promised to send me Statements of the numbers of French and American vessels which have entered our Ports the last three or four years— Mr and Mrs Frye called at our door this Evening but without stopping.

22. V: I received an invitation this morning to attend the laying of the corner stone of the City Hall, on the Judiciary Square, just back of our house— There was a procession, Masonic, and municipal, from Strother’s Hotel, to the ground. I attended at the Hotel at nine O’Clock, and walked in the procession. The corner Stone was laid by Mr Hewitt Grand Master of the lodge, after a prayer by Mr Hawley, an Oration by John Law, and some other Speeches and Ceremonies— The Sun was scorching, and the Solemnities occupied between three and four hours of time. After it was over I attended at the Office, and was there straitened for want of time. I received three despatches from A. Gallatin, one of which requires an immediate answer— As I was walking home I was overtaken by Mrs Adams and Charles who had been to Georgetown and bought a fowling piece that I had promised him. The Evening was cool.

23. IV:30. I begin from this day to write by morning candle-light, without which I shall certainly not have the Report upon weights and measures prepared for the next Session of Congress. The same motive compels me to desist from my Morning Baths, and to abridge this diary to a record of five or six lines a day. At the Office, a Mr Wilcocks of Philadelphia called upon me, and brought a Letter from his brother, who about three years ago was taken by the Spaniards in California, and has formed connections there and settled himself for life in that Country. When the Macedonian sailed for the South-Sea, Captain Downes at the solicitation of Wilcocks’s relations was requested to make enquiries after him, which he did; and found that he had got into as comfortable quarters that he did not incline to come home. Lieutenant Percival brought home these advices from Captain Downes last winter, and they were communicated to Mr Wilcocks at Philadelphia. His Letter now from his brother, dated in October 1818. confirms the information. He also came to enquire if I had received any further accounts from Captain Downes, but I had not. A young man from Boston by the name of Lienow came with an application for admission into the Corps of Cadets; he brought me a Letter of recommendation from Degrand, and had several others to Mr Calhoun. I directed him to go with all his recommendations to Major Van Deventer, Chief Clerk of the War Department. A man by the name of Kenan, brought a petition to the President for the remission of a penalty, forfeiture of a vessel supposed to have been incurred by the Captain’s bringing in a Slave of his own on board of her. The Secretary of the Treasury being absent he came to me, with his Petition, which I took and promised to forward to the President— I gave him also a certificate to the Collector of Norfolk that the petition would be forwarded, which he supposed would prevent the seizure of his vessel. Mr W. Lee came to the Office instead of A. Mitchell who is very ill, with a broken blood-vessel; in behalf of M. M. Noah’s application for an appointment as Chargé d’Affaires at Vienna. I told him I had sent Noah’s Letters to the President, who had returned them without any directions or remarks: but Mr Noah might be told that no Charge d’Affaires at Vienna could be appointed without the concurrence of the Senate. Mrs Adams and the children spent this Evening at Mr Frye’s— Mr Petry the French Consul General was here, and I had much conversation with him upon the subject of their and our discriminating duties— The motive for France’s aversion to removing them is that her Seamen cannot navigate ships so cheaply as ours. 1. because they are less expeditious. 2. because they are trammeled with expensive Marine Ordinances—

24. IV: From which hour till past Noon, with the exception of the Breakfast hour, I was absorbed in the Report upon Weights and Measures. At the Office Mr Mariano came, and informed me that he was going to Baltimore to-morrow, and thence after two or three days to New-York and Boston— And he asked me for a Letter of recommendation. He called again at my house this Evening, and I gave him one to P. P. F. Degrand— Mr Mariano says he shall return here before the commencement of the Session of Congress, and hopes I shall have employment for him— Mr Petry called at the Office, and gave me the Statements he had promised me last Evening of French and American Tonnage employed in the trade between the United States and France— I wrote to the President, and by the shortness of time that I have left for Office hours, with the Mails and franking of Packets, can do scarcely any thing else. I now waste the Evenings upon the Newspapers.

25. IV: I now sit down the moment after rising, to my task, in which I write slowly, with great difficulty, and much to my own dissatisfaction— My division of my subject remains as I struck it out; on first beginning the Report three years since— But my plan and many of my opinions vary as I write. My views of the subject multiply. Different aspects present themselves of the same materials— I approve and disapprove of the new French System— I admire its design, and the Spirit and Perseverance with which it has been pursued. I think it erroneous in some of its principles, and impracticable in many of its provisions. The enquiry into natural standards has led me into speculations which by many may be thought ridiculous or absurd— I am going into a Commentary upon the old English Statutes relating to weights and measures which will be dry and tedious, and am in constant danger of consuming the little time left me, for preparing the Report, without being ready for it at the next meeting of Congress. At the Office I wrote to the President, and also to T. B. Johnson, to make some enquiries about the weights and measures of Louisiana. I rode home with Mrs Adams in the Carriage.

26. III:45.Mr Frye, wrote me a note to ask for half an hour’s Conversation with him. I sent for him immediately and he came to the Office. He wanted my advice. He is first Clerk in the Office of the Paymaster General. Robert Brent was in that Office, which he resigned only a few weeks before he died. But for fourteen Months before he resigned, he was incapable by sickness of performing any duty, and the whole business of a laborious, and highly responsible office devolved upon Frye. He performed it faithfully; and after Brent’s resignation applied to the President for the appointment— It was given to Major Towson—and Frye then applied to Calhoun, for additional compensation for having performed fourteen Months the duty of Pay-master General— Calhoun not answering his first application, he repeated it, and Van Deventer by Calhoun’s direction since he left the City answers, that Brent having received the pay, there is no appropriation for an extra-compensation to Frye.— He brought and shewed me now several papers shewing precedents of similar allowances to others; one particularly, by a special direction of the President, upon a reference from Crawford upon an application of N. Lufborough, for performing the duties of Comptroller of the Treasury; while Bacon held the Office; but was sick and absent, and received the Salary— There are two annual appropriations for such accounts as may be admitted on a due course of examination at the Treasury. It is in general terms, and has usually been applied to cases of this kind. Lufborough was paid from it, and Frye says Crawford has given good portions of this appropriation to both the Dickins’s his Clerks— Frye says too that Calhoun makes profuse allowances for extra-services to military Officers— He is intensely exasperated against him; thinking him the cause of Towson’s having got the appointment of Pay-master General, and thinking him both personally hostile and unjust to him in this case— Frye has been upwards of twenty years a Clerk in the Paymaster’s Office, always faithful, assiduous and correct. The case of Lufborough is so precisely in
point, that I advised Frye to renew the application to Calhoun, and send him, a Copy of Lufborough’s Letter to Crawford, with the President’s decision upon it. That case however occurred before the Act of Congress of the 20th. of April 1818, which prohibits any allowance to Clerks other than their fixed Salaries. I suppose that act, will prevent Frye’s obtaining the compensation which he really has earned, without an act of Congress to authorize it. I wrote to the President— There was a heavy thundershower, and a cool Evening.

27. IV: The shortness of my time, and the magnitude of my task, compel me to work upon it the Sunday, as well, as other days— I wrote all this morning upon my draft, and am deeply engaged in the examination of the old English Statutes upon Weights and Measures— We all attended Church, and Mrs Smith went with Mrs Adams. Mr M’Cormick read prayers for the 13th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Colossians III:15. “Let the Peace of God rule in your hearts.” a Sermon written with great elegance of Style; but having more of Common Place, in the Doctrines, than many others which he reads. Religion and Piety were the sources from which the Peace of God was to be made the possession of the Heart. He made also a few extemporaneous remarks upon the second Lesson of the day, which was the Story of the good Samaritan— My thoughts wandered in despite of my will, and my attention was not sufficiently assiduous to the services of the day. Daniel Brent was here after Church to enquire if there was a Letter to him from the President; but there was not. After dinner I took a short walk with Mrs Adams and the Children.

28. IV: I am now losing no time, for immediately after rising I sit down to my work; but from that time till Noon with the intermission of breakfast the hours fly so rapidly, that my journal, as much as I have abridged it, runs in arrears. It was one O’Clock this day before I reached the Office, and as Mrs Adams was going to visit her cousin Mr George Johnson, I rode with her as far as the Office. At the Office I wrote a short Letter to the President, and another to Wait the printer at Boston, concerning the secret Journals— The Abbe Correa had sent to ask a Conference with me, concerning his proposal that we should appoint Commissioners to enquire into the captures by armed vessels fitted out in our Ports, of Portuguese vessels and Cargoes— I appointed to-morrow at two O’Clock to see him— Looking this day into Rees’s Encyclopaedia, Article Coins, I found reference to two works, one by Martin Folkes, and another by the late Lord Liverpool upon the English Coins, which I want to consult— I found and sent to my house the Edinburgh Review of the latter, and gave it a cursory perusal this Evening. It suggested some ideas— Short walk after dinner.

29. V: An hour latter than my allotted time. But my eyes begin to complain— That hour however was lost for the Journal which ran back another day— Mary Hellen was taken ill with a fever. At the Office I had a visit from Mr Anderson first Comptroller of the Treasury, who has been applied to, from Petersburg Virginia, for a suspension of the Act of Congress of 15 May last imposing a Tonnage duty of 18 dollars a Ton upon French Vessels, in behalf of a French vessel arrived there, which sailed from France 25 May; and therefore could not possibly know the existence of the Law— So that bonds might be taken instead of payment; on the presumption that Congress will at least remit these duties at their next Session— But there is no discretion given to the Executive to suspend the Law in this respect; and so Mr Anderson had already concluded— I asked him what had been done in the case of the duties collected on the Snuff which came in the Spanish Brig Fortuna; upon which there were applications from La Serna and afterwards from Vives, and about which I had spoken to him and Mr Crawford in the beginning of June— He had forgotten the case but took a minute of it and promised me an answer— The Abbe Correa came according to appointment and in a conference of about an hour, urged the proposal which he had made in a Note, for the appointment of Commissioners to ascertain the amount of Portuguese property taken by privateers armed fitted out and manned in Ports of the United States, and sailing under the flag of Artigas. I stated to him the objections that there would be to the appointment of
such Commissioners to perform duties already assigned to our judicial tribunals. He had no confidence in our judges. He was perfectly satisfied with the dispositions of the Executive; but the Nation must be answerable to others for the Acts of its People. These depredations had excited great resentment among the Portuguese, which others (the English) were always ready to inflame— I told him they had the same complaint against others as against us— The Pirates were of all Nations— He said the same complaints had been made to England who had given ample satisfaction— They had hung some of the Pirates, and did not admit the Artigas flag into their Ports— I finally told him that the President would decide upon the proposal after full deliberation; probably not till after his return to this City, and upon consultation with the members of the administration. I should then answer his Note. He said he must embark for Brazil in the course of the next Month; but should present Mr Amado to me as Charge d’Affaires, and my answer might be addressed to him— I was sometime at the Office, weighing wheat and Coins.

30. IV: Commencement day at Cambridge. Dr Huntt was here to see Mary Hellen, who continues very unwell. General Parker brought to the Office a second Letter from Mr Byers of New York, concerning the Island newly discovered in the South-Sea; and the project of sending vessels there to catch Whales and Seals. I enclosed it again to the President— Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us, and her husband called here this Evening.

31. IV:Mrs K. Brown of Georgetown called here this Morning. Mr Correa came to the Office and introduced Mr Amado, as the Chargè d’Affaires of Portugal during his absence— But he has no thought of returning here. He says his king has made him so soft a cushion to repose upon there, that he thinks he shall not leave it. Having the appointment of a Privy Counsellor of the Finances, and a Commandery of the Order of Christ, rewards which are usually bestowed on Persons of the highest rank and long and eminent services— He also said that Count Palmella was now on his passage from Lisbon to Brazil, where he was two years since or more appointed Minister of foreign Affairs— I had found by calculation that according to the weight of the silver English penny as marked in the Statute of 51. Henry 3d.—1266.32 kernels of wheat the English shilling of the new coinage ought to weigh a fraction more than 124 kernels— With the help of Thruston, I weighed two shillings, selecting the kernels, from a half bushel of wheat raised in this neighbourhood and bought at a venture. we found them each to weigh 124 corns turning the scale, but less than half a Troy grain. Mr Brent brought three samples of other wheat which did not weigh so much, but I am strongly confirmed in the belief that average wheat will turn out to give its select kernels of uniform weight; and that as a foundation for a positive Standard, it is perhaps as good as water. Evening cool.

Day. Range of my rising hour from III:30 to VI. Average about half past IV:— I now am assiduously reading or writing upon weights and measures, till 9 or 10. and after breakfast, till past Noon. I seldom reach my Office before one, and then am constantly engaged in the current business till near six. I then return home to dine, and employ the Evening in reading the Newspapers; which since the days have begun to shorten I am enabled to do. The Summer heats are still so oppressive as partially to disqualify me for assiduous labour, and the progress of my draft of a Report upon weights and measures continually opening new fields of enquiry, supplying new information and correcting erroneous opinions, absorbs nine or ten hours of every day leaving no time for the bath, scarcely a moment for the Journal, and less than six hours for the Office.
